There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"acd1ba06-c4be-4483-8ed4-11213b4edb46\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"I'll provide the solution in the format you requested.\\n\\n## Root Cause Fault 1\\n### Type: 2. container memory load\\n### Description: High memory usage on Service Instances, indicating potential memory exhaustion.\\n### Location: checkoutservice-2\\n### Justification:\\n1. `checkoutservice-2` has a high `container_memory_usage_MB` value (up) across multiple alerts.\\n2. Similar high memory usage is observed on other `checkoutservice` instances (checkoutservice-0, checkoutservice-1).\\n3. The `container_memory_usage_MB` metric is directly related to the `container` component of the `Service_Instance`, which is hosted on a `Host` node.\\n4. High memory usage can lead to performance degradation and crashes, causing the observed symptoms.\\n5. The `hosted_on` relationship between `Service_Instance` and `Host` indicates that the fault is localized to a single node.\\n\\nPropagation Path: `checkoutservice-2 --(has_instance)--> checkoutservice --(control_flow)--> frontend --(control_flow)--> productcatalogservice --(data_flow)--> productcatalog`\\n\\n## Root Cause Fault 2\\n### Type: 12. node memory consumption\\n### Description: High memory usage on the Host node, indicating potential memory exhaustion.\\n### Location: node-5\\n### Justification:\\n1. `node-5` has a high `system.memory.used` value (up) across multiple alerts.\\n2. The `system.memory.used` metric is directly related to the `Host` node.\\n3. High memory usage on the Host node can cause memory exhaustion and performance degradation, leading to the observed symptoms.\\n4. The `hosted_on` relationship between `Service_Instance` and `Host` indicates that the fault is localized to a single node.\\n5. The `host` node is a shared resource among multiple `Service_Instance` instances, including `checkoutservice-2`.\\n\\nPropagation Path: `node-5 --(hosts)--> checkoutservice-2 --(has_instance)--> checkoutservice --(control_flow)--> frontend --(control_flow)--> productcatalogservice --(data_flow)--> productcatalog`\\n\\n## Root Cause Fault 3\\n### Type: 14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n### Description: High disk write I/O on the Host node, indicating potential disk saturation.\\n### Location: node-5\\n### Justification:\\n1. `node-5` has a high `system.disk.writes` value (up) across multiple alerts.\\n2. The `system.disk.writes` metric is directly related to the `Host` node.\\n3. High disk write I/O can cause disk saturation and performance degradation, leading to the observed symptoms.\\n4. The `hosted_on` relationship between `Service_Instance` and `Host` indicates that the fault is localized to a single node.\\n5. The `host` node is a shared resource among multiple `Service_Instance` instances, including `checkoutservice-2`.\\n\\nPropagation Path: `node-5 --(hosts)--> checkoutservice-2 --(has_instance)--> checkoutservice --(control_flow)--> frontend --(control_flow)--> productcatalogservice --(data_flow)--> productcatalog`\\n\\nRanking:\\n1. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-2-KG", "fault_id": "67", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"df2fe16b-6127-4894-88dc-972e9d8fca9e\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. This alert is closely followed by another alert `2022-03-21 19:17:00.000 | METRIC | shippingservice-0 | container_cpu_usage_seconds | up`, which suggests a similar issue on `shippingservice-0`. Both services are responsible for managing shipping-related data, and a disk read I/O issue could cause them to become unresponsive or produce incorrect results. The propagation path: `shippingservice-0 --(hosted_on)--> node-5 --(hosts)--> frontend-0 --(control_flow)--> productcatalogservice-0`, suggests that the disk issue on `shippingservice-0` could have caused a decrease in performance on `productcatalogservice-0`, which in turn affected `frontend-0`.", "propagation_path": "shippingservice-0 --(hosted_on)--> node-5 --(hosts)--> frontend-0 --(control_flow)--> productcatalogservice-0"}]}, "ttr": 120.90516972541809, "error": null, "past_steps": null}
{"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-2-KG", "fault_id": "70", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"cec027f6-0ad4-4d39-8023-faa4d3d3daab\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. The `container_network_receive_packets.eth0` metric alert on `frontend-2` indicates that disk space pressure may be causing issues.", "propagation_path": "node-6 --(hosts)--> frontend2-0 --(hosted_on)--> redis-cart2-0 --(data_flow)--> frontend-2"}, {"type": "container network latency", "description": "High network latency affecting the `adservice` service instance on `node-5`, causing slow response times.", "location": "adservice-0", "justification": "The `container_network_receive_MB.eth0` metric alert on `adservice-0` indicates high network transmission. The `container_network_receive_packets.eth0` metric alert on `cartservice-0` and `checkoutservice-1` suggests similar issues on these instances. The `container_network_receive_packets.eth0` metric alert on `cartservice-2` and `checkoutservice-2` indicates similar issues on these instances. The `container_network_latency` metric alert on `adservice-2` suggests that high network latency is affecting this instance. The `container_network_latency` metric alert on `adservice-0` indicates that high network latency is affecting this instance.", "propagation_path": "node-5 --(hosts)--> adservice-0 --(has_instance)--> adservice-0 --(data_flow)--> adservice-0"}]}, "ttr": 95.85169982910156, "error": null, "past_steps": null}
{"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-2-KG", "fault_id": "74", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"712aa034-c6c0-4a96-a170-ac1b9554eb47\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Alert `container_threads` is up on adservice-0, suggesting that the service instance is experiencing high CPU usage.\\n\\t3. This suggests that the high memory usage on adservice-0 could be due to the service instance being over-allocated or experiencing high resource utilization.\\n* **Propagation Path**: adservice-0 --(instance_of)--> adservice --(control_flow)--> frontend-0 --(hosted_on)--> node-5\\n\\n**Fault 2**\\n* **Type**: 1. container CPU load\\n* **Description**: Elevated CPU usage on a service instance, leading to potential performance issues.\\n* **Location**: adservice-2 (Service_Instance)\\n* **Justification**:\\n\\t1. The propagation path `adservice-2 --(hosted_on)--> node-5 --(hosts)--> node-1` shows that adservice-2 is hosted on node-5, which is also hosted on node-1. This suggests that the high CPU usage on adservice-2 could be due to the node's limited resources or high load.\\n* **Propagation Path**: adservice-2 --(hosted_on)--> node-5 --(hosts)--> node-1\\n\\n**Fault 3**\\n* **Type**: 8. container read I/O load\\n* **Description**: Elevated read I/O load on a service instance, leading to potential performance issues.\\n* **Location**: frontend-2 (Service_Instance)\\n* **Justification**:\\n\\t1. This suggests that the high read I/O load on frontend-2 could be due to the node's limited resources or high load.\\n* **Propagation Path**: frontend-2 --(hosted_on)--> node-6 --(hosts)--> node-1\\n\\nRanking the faults in order of most likely to least likely:\\n\\n1. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-2-KG", "fault_id": "76", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"a23f2596-2fd3-40d3-b31c-b42ecbc2c58d\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step.
